assessment.title: Anatomy and Direction of the Urinary System

question.body: Where are the kidneys compared to the spinal column?

response.feedback: Incorrect. The kidneys are not above the spinal column. The spinal column runs between the kidneys.

Correct. The kidneys are located on either side of the spinal column; the spinal column is located between the kidneys. The right kidney is usually slightly lower than the left. Its close proximity to the liver pushes the right kidney downward.
Incorrect. The kidneys are not below the spinal column. The spinal column is between the kidneys.
Incorrect. Proximal means inward toward the trunk. The kidneys are lateral to (on the sides of) the spinal column.

no_response.feedback: Please try to answer the question.

part.hint: The two kidneys are equally distant from the spinal column.
The spinal column is bisected by the midsagittal plane.

question.body: Urine travels in what direction from the kidney through the ureter to the bladder?

response.feedback: Correct. Urine travels down from the kidneys through the ureters into the bladder.
Incorrect. This would mean that the urine moves up toward the head.
Incorrect. Proximal means towards the trunk; that is, further into the body from the extremities. Urine starts flowing from the kidneys through the ureters downward to the bladder.
Incorrect. Deep means away from the surface further into the body.

part.hint: Typically, gravity aids in moving urine into the bladder.
